"While no one is suggesting that countries abandon biofuels,"

Well then let me be the first. Don't burn your food. Eat it.
And unless you have all the water and land that you need to feed all of your people don't take food acres out of production to make some non-consumable crop for bio-fuel either.

Corn ethanol is the biggest joke around. Corn is one of the most inefficient biofuel crop you can think of using. If we converted all of the arable farmland in the U.S. into corn production, the ethanol produced would only be about FIVE PERCENT of our needs - and then there will be no corn (and no doubt other carbo-containing crops) at all for food. Gasohol also produces LESS energy than gasoline or ethanol alone because each are efficient under substantially different pressure and air mixture conditions - trying to burn both at once lessens the efficiency (stoichiometry) of both of them. You get less energy and less work out of the mix than either one alone.

Look up "STOICHIOMETRIC GASOLINE ETHANOL" It's all verfiable and should show what a scam gasohol (E-90, E-85, etc) truly is. So WHY are we doing it anyway?

I've been saying this for 10 years now and still most people are clueless thanks to the media. You write, "For example, the Treasury may receive less revenue over time if taxpayers increasingly distrust government because they perceive their tax dollars are wasted." That sounds like Tea Party rhetoric.

Taxpayers may "increasingly distrust government" because:
- Congressional action is bought by lobbyists
- Corporations like GE game the tax system
- Bank bailouts and Fed support enrich Goldman Sachs
- Hedge fund managers pay capital gains rates not income tax
- Trillions are parked offshore waiting to be repatriated (again) at insanely low rates

Taxpayer distrust will flow not from the idea that tax dollars are wasted. Rather distrust comes from the realization that individual taxpayers get stuck with the bill for (and social consequences of) unbridled greed while the plutocrats and corporate behemoths get a free ride.

That most of the media and pundits have described Rep. Ryan's Path to Poverty plan as "brave" and "serious" shows just how shallow and out of touch with reality our chattering classes are. For them, I have to ask:

What is brave and serious about a Republican using deficits that conservatives created to propose abolishing Medicare, and replacing it with a program that would cost more to implement while leaving most seniors without quality health care?

What is brave and serious about a Republican proposiong a deficit "reduction" plan that would eliminate the tax on wealthy estates and lower taxes on the wealthiest Americans, while raising taxes on the poor and working class?

What is brave and serious about a Republican proposing a deficit "reduction" plan that puts almost all of the burden of spending cuts on the middle class, working class, and poor?

What is brave and serious about a Republican proposing a deficit "reduction" plan that projects reduced deficits, increased jobs, and higher economic growth only by cooking the books and using ridiculous assumptions?

The simple fact is that Mr. Ryan's Path to Poverty is cowardly as it simply goes along with the interests of the Republicans' billionaire sugar daddies while ignoring the role that conservative economic policies played in creating the deficits, eviscerating middle class security, and undermining our economy.

If Mr. Ryan wanted to show he was "brave" and "serious" he would acknowledge that economic growth is the primary short term way to reduce the deficit, and that military spending cuts, corporate subsidy reductions, increased immigration, and the types of sensible efficiencies promoted by health care reform are what are necessary to achieving long term fiscal sanity. Unfortunately, Mr. Ryan is neither brave nor serious. Instead, he is just the Cowardly Lion, but without a heart.

This is just what Republicans want - a generation war to make people forget all about the class war and about the richest one percent owning a third of all the wealth. It's just another wedge issue the GOP is so adeptly famous for.

When I look at the Paul Ryan's "Path to Prosperity", I see something that is very much like Newt Gingrich's "Contract with America". Which is very similar to what Ronald Reagan was pushing, which is not totally different from what Barry Goldwater believed in. This is just the same old ideas with numbers that have never added up.

The other piece of this puzzle: Deficits were dropping steadily from 1945 to 1980. Then all of a sudden, in 1981, shortly after Reagan pushed through big tax cuts for the rich, deficits went up again. Then in the mid-1990's Bill Clinton raised taxes on the rich again, and suddenly the budget deficit was gone. Then, in 2001, after George W Bush's tax cuts went through, the deficit began to rise again. Are you seeing the pattern here?

The thing is, I'm pretty sure Paul Ryan proposed this budget in order to have it rejected. The libertarian wing of the Tea Party thinks they would do best with essentially no federal government at all. A shutdown gives them exactly what they want. And I expect it will work about as well as Newt's attempt at the same gambit.

This is a perfectly predictable consequence of making the Bush - now Obama - tax cuts permanent. Both parties bear responsibility for the current situation.

The deficit and debt projections resulting from the tax cuts are huge. No reasonable budget proposal can reduce long-range deficits to acceptable levels without revenue increases. In the absence of a tax hike, desperate swipes at spending, such as the Ryan Medicare plan, can be expected. We shouldn't entirely blame Congressman Ryan - a Democratic House, Senate, and President created the mess which he's trying to exploit.

President Obama could have let the Bush tax cuts expire. Instead, he made them his own. Now he has to cut spending to make up the shortfall. Good luck!

escalating health care costs are the problem.  So why does health care escalate?  One simple answer is unbridled greed.  Whose greed you might ask?  Doctors?  Real income has gone down by 15% over the last 20 years.  Drug companies?  10% of the overall cost of health care and holding (including new and better drugs).  No the answer is administrative costs of insurance companies, hospitals and nursing homes. With the largest health care system in the world, economy of scale does not apply.  Estimates of 20% to 30% all health care dollars goes to administrative costs.  In other health care systems this cost is 10% to 12%.  That means that up to 20% of health care is waste.  In real dollars that means that $480 billion dollars in going to waste EVERY year.  Over the last 20 years the percentage of administrative cost as slowly but surely increased.  Assuming that waste has grown from 20% noted by consumer reports in 1993 to 30% today, we have wasted at least two trillion dollars to administrative cost over the last 27 years.  I mean wasted.  The only function of health care administration is ensure the administrator is overpaid and under-worked and that every other health care provider is overworked and underpaid.  It can be equally said that the only function of insurance company's administrator is to ensure that they collect premiums and rarely if never pay out.

As usual, these proposals are a giveaway to private interests. The medicare plan in particular does nothing more than line the pockets of the CEOs of the health care plans. One only has to look at their annual reports, to wonder just haw they can pay their executives millions on bonuses and stock options. In several cases, tens of millions. The administrative costs are as much as 40% of the premiums. that is accomplished by rationing the actual health care a rate payer gets.

Yep, good old republicans again, looking out for the citizens. Of course those citizens are a small class of the general citizens that actually need a health care program.

Oh, and then there is the Trickle Down theory. Tax less and the rich will spend more. The richest 400 Americans have 20% of the wealth. The great majority of them pay a lower tax rate than the average tax payer. How does this happen? It happens because much of the very wealthy get their income from dividends and capital gains, which are taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income. You Mr. Citizen pay a higher rate on the interest from your meager savings account than the wealthy pay on their income.

Look up the Forbes 400 wealthy Americans, and see just how many of them actually put people top work with their billions in wealth. For instance, several of them are fund managers, who do indeed put people to work. Unfortunately those people are in China and India, where the jobs they eliminated with their leveraged buyouts went after they loted the parent companies. Several of these super rich are heirs to fortunes, and yes they do put people to work. They need maids, cooks, butlers, yacht crews, gardeners, and other domestic help for their estates, here and in other countries. Only two of them as far as I can see, actually run a major manufacturer, a company that employs thousands or contributes to the economy with investing in start ups new technology, or other enterprises. Oh they do give to the arts, and some foundations, but that is because of their social circle.

Again, we can see the influence money has on the conservatives. When you see one of their program, look and see who really benefits. I will give you odds it is not you.

You are absolutely correct. It seems to be a standard tactic used by Republicans to make people believe they can magically obtain the same level of services they get now for less money than is currently spent, proposing some kind of fixed "voucher" in place of the bottomless well that characterizes current health care spending. Make a proposal to perhaps establish guidelines that make sure that procedures covered should actually be proven to be useful for a patient and you get accused of rationing healthcare. But establish a static voucher per patient and somehow that is not rationing, instead it's providing incentives to help the "marketplace" reduce healthcare costs as if such a free marketplace exists. How about allowing patients to use their vouchers to get healthcare in foreign countries where doctors fees are much lower (as Dean Baker has proposed)? Not likely to see any proposals for that as it would provide too much competition for American doctors and their high paying jobs, but thats how truly free markets would work in healthcare if the Republicans actually believed in capitalism, pity they do not. Vouchers are really a fiscal scoundrel's last resort, as if anyone in the upper classes thinks you can get something for nothing, they know the vouchers are inadequate, just as voucher amounts for education are always inadequate when proposed as a solution for the current state of public education, the goal is not to improve education, just pay as little as you can for the current poor state of affairs. In healthcare the goal is just the same, make sure that the rich with their gold plate plate healthcare plans can get anything they want whenever they want and for the rest of us, well we get just what a voucher will get us and thats that. Vouchers truly are healthcare rationing. Thanks for providing the clarity on the true intent of the current proposals.

I still recall when my father was a petroleum company executive during a refinery strike during my younger years and him telling how he had to low-crawl to his car after his month of working to keep the refinery operating. I remember the wives of the workers in that strike coming to our rural home with their children, and asking for food and toilet paper. I recall my mother answering the door with a revolver in one hand hidden behind her back. I recall us setting up a a pantry in the garage and my mother telling them she couldn't feed them all but would help in emergencies. I recall my father expressing amazement that after low-crawling to the car, the union workers opened the gate and waved him out. I remember his consternation when my mother showed him the garage pantry and explained why they'd waved him out. She said the strike was between the men, and union or not, she'd always share her food with mothers and children. I remember our house being shot at and seeing the bullet holes in the living room window.

I recall one of my father's friends over one evening talking to him about a railroad strike. He told of how union workers had been found along the rail bed beaten black and blue. About that moment he looked up and remarked to my father that "little ears were nearby" and he'd better stop or there'd be nightmares. I was sent to bed.

I recall the news stories on WGN radio about acid being thrown into truckers' faces during trucking strikes.

I recall the death threats sent to my parents about kidnapping and killing me. I recall at age 7 people in Halloween masks attacking the windows on my bedroom and I then recall being taken to St. Louis where a large black German Shepherd named Windy and I were trained together for my protection. I recall the annual re-training through my eleventh year. That probably had a lot to do with my father regularly took me overseas with him.

That is the era back to which Congressman Ryan and his bought, phony, grass-root supporters want to take us: the era of real class warfare. It's sick. They're morally corrupt.

The reason the budget deficits are soaring is not, as Paul Ryan seems to believe, that taxes are too low, but because unemployment is too high. And look at the statistics. Census figures show that from April 1, 2000 to April 1, 2010 US population grew from 281,422,000 to 308,745,000, an increase of 27,323,000. Bureau of labor statistics show that from April, 2000 to April, 2010 nonfarm payrolls decreased from 131,660,000 to 130,162,000.

Macroeconomics is an interplay of numerous variables and nothing has just one cause. But the fact is that population growth of .9% per year is unsustainable in the long run. Population growth, together with Wall Street corruption which led to the housing bubble and collapse, is largely responsible for today's high unemployment rates.

Shutting the government down to force women to bear children they do not want and cannot support is not just cruel, it wreaks havoc with the US budget over the longer term. We need leadership which encourages smaller family size in the new era of constrained natural resources.

Once again, Krugman misses the point. He gives hints that he knows this, but he still persists in analyzing the so-called budget proposal as if it is a budget proposal. It isn't. It is a proposal to shift power and wealth to the powerful and wealthy by making sure that laissez-faire conditions envelop private enterprise in a blanket of corporate profits. And the core strategy for doing this is to make sure that government has no resources to do anything and no capacity to be a countervailing force to large corporations.
The analysis of the budget is irrelevant. And as long as the debate remains focused on budgets, the real issues will be ignored.

This is part of the ideology to which right-wing Republicans (rwGOP) have been mindlessly genuflecting for 30 years since Reagan and Stockman bought into Freidman’s simplistic economic models—apparently, to make the mathematics easier, he assumed human behavior, individually and collectively as a society, has no effect on economics and, hence, could be excluded as factors from his models. Apparently, Friedman also didn’t study Forrester (MIT), who showed in the 60’s that a predictive model is no better than it’s underlying assumptions. Nevertheless, the rwGOP has relentlessly pursued “free market” and deregulation ideology as though human greed, avarice, insecurity, ego, success, failure, desire for power, wealth, and control doesn’t matter—that it’s all somehow disconnected from the relationship between government, business, social services and safety nets. But that’s not a serious issue to the rwGOP—actually, they like it this way: the rwGOP advances their political agenda by using and abusing economic instability, vis-à-vis “The Shock Doctrine” http://www.powells.com/biblio/7-9780312427993-2 ; using disinformation and lies; creating Fear, Uncertainty, and Doubt; and, for all practical purposes, waging economic warfare against the U.S. Government and 97% of the American people.

So, of course, neither can Ryan’s budget be remotely serious: the rwGOP agenda (and budget proposal) is far removed from one designed to restore America’s economic strength.

Why? Their entire political agenda promotes “liberty” and deregulation to rape the planet, eliminate American rights and protections, and devolve the American Democratic Republic, by and for the people, into a plutarchy, by and for the extremely wealthy and corporations--all for limitless irresponsibility, destructiveness, power, and unbridled, greedy profiteering, without consequences.

Consider the $61 Billion in budget cuts the rwGOP is using to threaten to shut-down the U.S. government: the deficit is about $1.3 Trillion ($1,300 Billion); and the debt is about $14.2 Trillion ($14,200 Billion). Simple arithmetic: 100 x $61Billion / $1,300Billion = 4.7% of the deficit; and 100 x $61Billion / $14,200Billion = 0.43% of the debt. No matter how you look at it, cutting the budget by $61Billion has virtually no meaningful fiscal impact on government operations, budget deficit or debt. Imagine that! That’s the same impotent impact on the debt and deficit as extending the Bush tax cuts and enabling corporations such as G.E. to claim $3.2Billion in tax refunds on $14.5 Billion in profits.

What is the impact? $61Billion in cuts facilitates undermining women’s rights, undermining education and teachers, Planned Parenthood, NPR, rejecting knowledge-based action (such EPA, DOE, climate change science), and undermining beneficial governmental services the rwGOP glibly perceive as “socialism” or “big government”.

It’s all just part of the big picture the rwGOP have been painting for 30 years since Reagan.
